spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Spellcasting. Princess Xedalli is an 11th-level spellcaster. Her spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 17}, +9 to hit with spell attacks). Princess Xedalli has the following wizard spells prepared:

trait.name: Fey Ancestry
entries: The elf has advantage on saving throws it makes to avoid or end the {@condition charmed} condition on itself, and magic can't put it to sleep.

trait.name: Special Equipment
entries: The elf wears a suit of elven chain.

trait.name: Unusual Nature
entries: The elf doesn't require sleep.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The elf makes two Scimitar attacks and uses Radiant Beam (if available). Spellcasting replaces two of these attacks, cantrip replaces one.

action.name: Scimitar
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) slashing damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) cold damage.

action.name: Vacuum Decay (3/Day)
entries: A magical beam of moonlight flashes out from Xedalli's hand in a 5-foot-wide, 60-foot-long line. Each creature in the line must make a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw, taking 18 ({@damage 4d8}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Creatures who fail the save begin to suffocate as a spherical vacuum forms around their head. At the start of each of their turns the creature can repeat the saving throw, ending the effect on a success.

bonus.name: Starlight Step (3/Day)
entries: The elf magically teleports up to 30 feet, along with anything it is wearing or carrying, to an unoccupied space it can see.

bonus.name: Summon Lunar Dragon (1/Day)
entries: The magically summons a {@creature young lunar dragon|BAM}. A summoned dragon appears in an unoccupied space that the summoner can see, acts on its own initiative count, and is an ally of its summoner. It remains for 10 minutes, until it or its summoner dies, or until its summoner dismisses it as an action.
An astral elf aristocrat is a brilliant, highborn leader gifted with magical abilities, including the power to channel sunlight and summon a solar dragon.

entries.name: Astral Elves
entries: Long ago, some elves ventured to the Astral Plane to be closer to their gods. There, they ceased to age and could exist indefinitely without sustenance.

Astral elves were among the first creatures to dwell in the Silver Void. As other explorers have reached for the stars, astral elves have had to reckon with violent neighbors and strange visitors. Over the eons, astral elves have clashed with numerous invaders, including psurlons, mind flayers, and githyanki. When dealing with others, astral elves customarily cover their faces with ornate visors, becoming faceless extensions of their gods. Their fierce devotion to the pantheon of elven deities is repaid with divine power. For example, the gods invest astral elf warriors with the power to channel the radiant energy of starlight through their weapons, just as they empower astral elf leaders with the ability to cast spells and summon solar dragons.

Astral elves ply the Astral Sea and Wildspace in ships of their own design. These ships are fashioned from crystals harvested from Wildspace systems and bound together with an organic, plant-based material that hardens like ceramic. The elves sculpt these substances in various configurations to create star moths (see the {@i Astral Adventurer's Guide}) and other vessels. The elves also reshape the petrified bodies of dead gods found adrift in the Silver Void, transforming them into floating cities and citadels.

Although the Silver Void is their home, astral elves often venture into Wildspace systems and place their ships and citadels in orbit around stars. Astral elves do this for several reasons. Proximity to a star allows the astral elves to forge pacts with solar dragons and to collect starlight, which the elves use to grow crystals and repair their ships. Most important, astral elves use their time outside the Deep Astral to replenish their numbers by having and raising children.

Many astral elves are thousands (in some cases tens of thousands) of years old. Whatever their disposition, their longevity gives astral elves a perspective on time that few other kinds of creatures can appreciate. Whether they choose to live in quiet contemplation or strike out to explore the far reaches of the multiverse, astral elves tend to see events happening elsewhere as having little or no meaning to them.

entries.name: Astral Elves of Xaryxis
entries: The adventure,{@i Light of Xaryxis}features an amoral astral elf society called the Xaryxian Empire. This empire is based in Xaryxispace, a Wildspace system illuminated by an enormous radiant sun named Xaryxis.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Prince Xeleth is a 16th-level spellcaster. His spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 18}, +11 to hit with spell attacks). Prince Xeleth has the following spells prepared:

spells: {@spell destructive wave} (pushes 20ft away on fail, 10ft on success)

trait.name: Fey Ancestry
entries: The elf has advantage on saving throws it makes to avoid or end the {@condition charmed} condition on itself, and magic can't put it to sleep.

trait.name: Special Equipment
entries: The elf wears a suit of elven chain and has the ring of starlight in his possession; loss of this artifact will eliminate the starlight ward trait below.

trait.name: Unusual Nature
entries: The elf doesn't require sleep.

trait.name: Starlight Ward
entries: Prince Xeleth has the spirits of three solar dragons bound to him, surrounded in the light of Xaryxis. Each dragon acts as a ward that has 100 hit points, sharing the vulnerabilities, resistances and immunities of Prince Xeleth. Whenever Prince Xeleth takes damage, the ward takes the damage instead. If this damage reduces the final ward to 0 hit points, Prince Xeleth takes any remaining damage. At the start of his turn a ward not a 0 hit points, regains all its hit points if it took no damage since last turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The elf makes as many Accretion Beam attacks as they have starlight wards.

action.name: Radiant Beam
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 300 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 1d4+5}) fire damage in melee, or 7 ({@damage 1d4+5}) radiant damage at range. A creature hit with this attack must make a {@dc 18} STR save or be pushed 20ft, if a creature fails by five or more ({@dc 13}) the creature is pushed 40 ft. The damage die increase each time a ward is reduced to 0 hit points.

bonus.name: Starlight Step (6/Day)
entries: The elf magically teleports up to 30 feet, along with anything it is wearing or carrying, to an unoccupied space it can see.
An astral elf aristocrat is a brilliant, highborn leader gifted with magical abilities, including the power to channel sunlight and summon a solar dragon.

entries.name: Astral Elves
entries: Long ago, some elves ventured to the Astral Plane to be closer to their gods. There, they ceased to age and could exist indefinitely without sustenance.

Astral elves were among the first creatures to dwell in the Silver Void. As other explorers have reached for the stars, astral elves have had to reckon with violent neighbors and strange visitors. Over the eons, astral elves have clashed with numerous invaders, including psurlons, mind flayers, and githyanki. When dealing with others, astral elves customarily cover their faces with ornate visors, becoming faceless extensions of their gods. Their fierce devotion to the pantheon of elven deities is repaid with divine power. For example, the gods invest astral elf warriors with the power to channel the radiant energy of starlight through their weapons, just as they empower astral elf leaders with the ability to cast spells and summon solar dragons.

Astral elves ply the Astral Sea and Wildspace in ships of their own design. These ships are fashioned from crystals harvested from Wildspace systems and bound together with an organic, plant-based material that hardens like ceramic. The elves sculpt these substances in various configurations to create star moths (see the {@i Astral Adventurer's Guide}) and other vessels. The elves also reshape the petrified bodies of dead gods found adrift in the Silver Void, transforming them into floating cities and citadels.

Although the Silver Void is their home, astral elves often venture into Wildspace systems and place their ships and citadels in orbit around stars. Astral elves do this for several reasons. Proximity to a star allows the astral elves to forge pacts with solar dragons and to collect starlight, which the elves use to grow crystals and repair their ships. Most important, astral elves use their time outside the Deep Astral to replenish their numbers by having and raising children.

Many astral elves are thousands (in some cases tens of thousands) of years old. Whatever their disposition, their longevity gives astral elves a perspective on time that few other kinds of creatures can appreciate. Whether they choose to live in quiet contemplation or strike out to explore the far reaches of the multiverse, astral elves tend to see events happening elsewhere as having little or no meaning to them.

entries.name: Astral Elves of Xaryxis
entries: The adventure,{@i Light of Xaryxis}features an amoral astral elf society called the Xaryxian Empire. This empire is based in Xaryxispace, a Wildspace system illuminated by an enormous radiant sun named Xaryxis.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: Prince Xeleth make one Accretion Beam attack

legendary.name: Teleport
entries: Prince Xeleth teleports up to 60 ft to an unoccupied space he can see

legendary.name: Rain (2 actions)
entries: Prince Xeleth warps starlight into the form of three astral seed pods which are magically hurled as ranged attacks. {@hit 11} 120 ft range {@damage 1d6+5} piercing damage. Primordial plane touched creatures who are hit must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or take one level of Exhaustion. Hit or miss the projectile becomes an Astral blight, in an unoccupied space next to the creature, acting on initiative count 10.

legendary.name: Cast a spell (3 Actions)
entries: Prince Xeleth cast a spell from his list of prepared spells of 5th level or lower

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Vaati's spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 20}). The Vaati can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The Vaati has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Air requirement
entries: if the majority of the Vaati is not in contact with air (e.g. coated in water, earth) then it has disadvantage on attack rolls, savings throws and ability checks, and take 20 damage at the start of each of its turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The planetar makes two Claw or two Wind Javelin attacks.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 4d6 + 7}) slashing damage.

action.name: Wind Javelin
entries: {@atk rw} automatic hit, range 120 ft., one target the Vaati can see. {@h}20 magical piercing damage.

action.name: Void
entries: if the Vaati is in contact with air, it summons a sheath of air around itself and then banishes all air within 30 ft of itself, creating a vacuum. While the sheath of air moves with it, this radius does not move with the Vaati, and lasts for 1 minute or until the Vaati loses {@status concentration} (as if it were {@status concentration||concentrating} on a spell). While in the void, the creature is suffocating and must make a {@dc 20} con save at the start of each of its turns, taking {@damage 4d8} force damage and gaining a level of {@condition exhaustion} on a failure, and taking half as much damage on a success.

An angel is a celestial agent sent forth into the planes to further its god's agenda for weal or woe. Its sublime beauty and presence can drive awestruck onlookers to their knees. Yet angels are destroyers too, and their appearance portends doom as often as it signals hope.

entries.name: Shards of the Divine
entries: Angels are formed from the astral essence of benevolent gods and are thus divine beings of great power and foresight.

Angels act out the will of their gods with tireless devotion. Even chaotic good deities command lawful good angels, knowing that the angels' dedication to order best allows them to fulfill divine commands. An angel follows a single driving purpose, as decreed by its deity. However, an angel is incapable of following commands that stray from the path of law and good.

An angel slays evil creatures without remorse. As the embodiment of law and good, an angel is almost never mistaken in its judgments. This quality can create a sense of superiority in an angel, a sense that comes to the fore when an angel's task conflicts with the goals of another creature. The angel never acquiesces or gives way. When an angel is sent to aid mortals, it is sent not to serve but to command. The gods of good therefore send their angels among mortals only in response to the most dire circumstances.

entries.name: Fallen Angels
entries: An angel's moral compass grants it a sense of infallibility that can sometimes spell its undoing. Angels are usually too wise to fall for a simple deception, but sometimes pride can lead one to commit an evil act. Whether intentional or accidental, such an act is a permanent stain that marks the angel as an outcast. Fallen angels retain their power but lose their connection to the deities from which they were made. Most fallen angels take their banishment personally, rebelling against the powers they served by seeking rulership over a section of the Abyss or a place among other fallen in the hierarchy of the Nine Hells. Zariel, the ruler of the first layer of the Nine Hells, is such a creature. Rather than rebel, some fallen angels resign themselves to an isolated existence on the Material Plane, living in disguise as simple hermits. If they are redeemed, they can become powerful allies dedicated to justice and compassionate service.

entries.name: Immortal Nature
entries: An angel doesn't require food, drink, or sleep.

entries.name: Planetar
entries: Planetars act as the weapons of the gods they serve, presenting a tangible representation of their deities' might. A planetar can call down rain to relieve a drought, or can loose an insect plague to devour crops. A planetar's celestial ears detect every falsehood, and its radiant eyes see through every deception.

Planetars are muscular and hairless and have opalescent green skin and white-feathered wings. They tower over most humanoids, brandishing immense swords with grace. Sometimes sent to aid powerful mortals on important tasks for good, planetars are especially fond of missions that involve battling fiends.

trait.name: Silence within the library
entries: The argus is the centre of a permanent silence spell. Additionally, whenever a creature starts its turn within the silence or enters the area for the first time on a turn, it must make a {@dc 17} Wisdom saving throw or be paralysed until the start of its next turn. A creature that succeeds on this save is immune to the paralysing effect of all Silences for the next 24 hours.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The argus has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Argus uses Storm of Hands and Eye Rays or uses Storm of Eyes and makes three claw attacks.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 30 ft., one target. {@h}34 ({@damage 4d12 + 8}) slashing damage.

action.name: Storm of hands {@recharge 4}
entries: Each creature of the Argus’s choice within a 20-ft radius of a point the Argus can see within 60 ft takes {@damage 20d6} bludgeoning damage, {@dc 20} dex save for half; on a failed save, a hand wraps around the creature’s throat, causing it to begin suffocating. A hand can be pried off by making a {@dc 20} strength check as an action.

action.name: Storm of eyes {@recharge}
entries: Each creature of the Argus’s choice within a 20-ft radius of a point the Argus can see within 60 ft must make a Charisma saving throw. On a successful save, nothing happens; on a failed save, the creature finds themselves staring out of the Argus’s space as its left eye appears on the Argus’s form.

The body is possessed; roll {@dice 1d8} to determine the personality of the possessor. The possessed creature retains none of its class features or proficiencies, other than charisma save proficiency. At the end of each of a possessed creature’s turns, it can make a Charisma save to end the effect; the effect also ends if the Argus dies. If the creature fails three charisma saves, then the possession becomes permanent. The possession can only be undone by releasing the possessed creature from the Argus (either by dispel evil and good, or by killing the Argus) and then reversing the possession (either by dispel evil and good, or by death and resurrection).

action.name: Eye Rays
entries: The argus shoots three of the following magical eye rays at random (reroll duplicates), choosing one to three targets it can see within 120 feet of it:

items.name: 1. Charm Ray
items.entry: The targeted creature must succeed on a {@dc 17} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition charmed} by the argus for 1 hour, or until the argus harms the creature.

items.name: 2. Paralyzing Ray
items.entry: The targeted creature must succeed on a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

items.name: 3. Fear Ray
items.entry: The targeted creature must succeed on a {@dc 17} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

items.name: 4. Slowing Ray
items.entry: The targeted creature must succeed on a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the target's speed is halved for 1 minute. In addition, the creature can't take reactions, and it can take either an action or a bonus action on its turn, not both. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

items.name: 5. Enervation Ray
items.entry: The targeted creature must make a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw, taking 36 ({@damage 8d8}) necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

items.name: 6. Telekinetic Ray
entries: If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 17} Strength saving throw or the argus moves it up to 30 feet in any direction. It is {@condition restrained} by the ray's telekinetic grip until the start of the argus's next turn or until the argus is {@condition incapacitated}.

If the target is an object weighing 300 pounds or less that isn't being worn or carried, it is moved up to 30 feet in any direction. The argus can also exert fine control on objects with this ray, such as manipulating a simple tool or opening a door or a container.

items.name: 7. Sleep Ray
items.entry: The targeted creature must succeed on a {@dc 17} Wisdom saving throw or fall asleep and remain {@condition unconscious} for 1 minute. The target awakens if it takes damage or another creature takes an action to wake it. This ray has no effect on constructs and undead.

items.name: 8. Petrification Ray
items.entry: The targeted creature must make a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the creature begins to turn to stone and is {@condition restrained}. It must repeat the saving throw at the end of its next turn. On a success, the effect ends. On a failure, the creature is {@condition petrified} until freed by the  {@spell greater restoration} spell or other magic.

items.name: 9. Disintegration Ray
entries: If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw or take 45 ({@damage 10d8}) force damage. If this damage reduces the creature to 0 hit points, its body becomes a pile of fine gray dust.

If the target is a Large or smaller nonmagical object or creation of magical force, it is disintegrated without a saving throw. If the target is a Huge or larger object or creation of magical force, this ray disintegrates a 10-foot cube of it.

items.name: 10. Death Ray
items.entry: The targeted creature must succeed on a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw or take 55 ({@damage 10d10}) necrotic damage. The target dies if the ray reduces it to 0 hit points.

items.name: 1. Melf
items.entry: An elven wizard who remembers he was looking for something, but is now quite old and senile. He does his best to keep up with modern lingo.

items.name: 2. Andarin Zarith
items.entry: A necromancer who just want to learn to how to resurrect a continents worth of undead and be left alone, and is thoroughly uninterested in your problems.

items.name: 3. Reginald Roundshield
items.entry: A younger dwarfish warrior who seeks the Axe of Dwarvish Lords to unite two feuding clans (he is the offspring of a Romeo and Juliet story).

items.name: 4. Lord Meltimber
items.entry: A lord who wants money, and went to the library of Vecna to get dirt on his enemies, also on his friends. Will suck up to whoever looks rich.

items.name: 5. Azael the Prince of Thunder
items.entry: A demon lord who was deposed centuries ago. He favours using lightning bolt and chain lightning to destroy his enemies, though he’s partial to the odd destructive wave. His possession grants none of these abilities.

items.name: 6. Hgraam
entries: A young druid who got real lost while looking for berries and just kinda wandered in.

items.name: 7. Jalynfein Oblodra
items.entry: A drow who was cast out of his house for his failure to learn psionics. He has endeavoured to find the secrets to arcane magic and lichdom instead, and cast down his former family.

items.name: 8. Christopher Onton
items.entry: A scholar who loves knowing things for the sake of knowing them. Well-meaning, but his lack of self-awareness means he can be snobbish at time.

items.name: 9. Xetzirbor
entries: A mind flayer who has gone weeks without eating a brain, and is now hungry to consume the brain of the smartest creature they can see. They aren’t irrational with hunger, but it’s their current priority.

items.name: 10. Yauln
items.entry: A stone giant seeking omens from the movements of the earth.

A creature that succeeds on this save is immune to the paralysing effect of all Silences for the next 24 hours.
